normalised: Arre yaar, load shedding again? it is like the uninvited guest that just keeps showing up, especially during the scorching Delhi summers. for those of you blessed enough not to know, load shedding is basically planned power outages – when the electricity company, like Tata Power here in Mumbai, deliberately cuts off power to certain areas for a specific time. think of it as a scheduled siesta for the grid, whether you like it or not.

normalised: why does this happen, you ask? well, imagine your chawl's water tank overflowing because everyone is using too much water at once. the power grid is kind of similar. when demand exceeds supply, especially during peak hours, the system can get overloaded and crash, causing a widespread blackout. load shedding is like a pressure valve, preventing a complete collapse. it is supposed to protect the whole system, but frankly, it mostly just protects the electricity companies from lawsuits, right?

normalised: the worst part is the uncertainty. you never really know when or for how long the power will be off. sometimes it is a quick thirty-minute blip, other times it stretches into a full-blown three-hour ordeal. and of course, it always seems to happen when you are in the middle of something important, like streaming the latest episode of "Family Man" or right as India is about to win a cricket match against Pakistan.
